content:
Posted: October 29, 2014
Personal rating: 8/10DLC: Worth it. New, more challenging maps. A nice addition to a short core game.What is Sanctum?Sanctum is a completely different take on the "Tower Defense" genre, it mixes up First Person Shooter elements in it and it does it well.About the gameplay:Here's the catch: If you have your mind set on "I'll only upgrade Towers!" or "I'll just shoot everything!", you're in for an embarrassing defeat. You cannot take everything head on here, you need to balance resources to deal with everything coming towards you: enemies that comes in large quantities, tough ones and tricky ones.Do you want to do the heavy lifting and shoot most of what's coming or use your towers while you kill whatever is left by the end? Or maybe you want to do both of these things? No problem, all three options are possible in this game.One of Sanctum's most known aspects is the maze building, you've got room and resources to create your personal enemy slaughtering course, it's far from putting one block here and another over there. If you want to survive the toughest levels of Sanctum you'll need to smart up and create mazes that will force enemies to walk as much as they can.Something that should be noted:Unlike Sanctum 2, there is absolutely no grinding in Sanctum 1. You start with everything the game gives you and after a short, optional, Tutorial you're free to do whatever you feel like in the first map. Play and learn, no hand holding here aside from the absolutely necessary.Tower Defense, because calling it "Resource Management" sounds like a boring disciplineBalancing resources here can be tough, they are rather scarce early on and woe betide the unprepared. Do you upgrade your towers or your guns? A difficult choice that can be the difference between victory or defeat. Towers and Weapons can be upgraded up to Level 6, and while they seem extremely cheap at first don't go thinking you can leave a bunch of Level 1 towers scattered and expect them to do heavy damage; enemies gets progressively stronger and soon you'll realize even your Level 3 towers are hardly doing any significant damage. And the same will apply to your guns if you ignore them.Upgrades will considerably power up your towers and guns, however they'll also become incredibly expensive and on shorter Campaign maps (with 20 or less waves), chances are, you won't be having lots of Level 6 towers even by the end of the map unless you focus more on them.Sanctum: Not an easy gameIf you are looking for a difficult game, Sanctum may be your cup of tea. The game is ruthless, but hardly unfair. It punishes poor planning and poor shooting accuracy and you'll probably be frustrated once you see that your carefully planned maze and towers did not work, but amazed when you beat that tough wave with your wits.The greatest challenge at the start is to understand how to balance your resources between weapons and towers, and until you find your own balance point, you'll be hitting that "Load Checkpoint" button quite often.The game is merciless and will not shy away from dropping tough enemies, although not without warning: the game provides a list for a number of incoming waves and what will be there. However Sanctum fail in one crucial point: there is no indication on how resilient the enemies will be. In one wave you may face a single, but extremely resistant, enemy and at the other wave the same type of enemy in larger numbers, however with much less HP. This can and will catch you off guard and is one of the very few times the game will play "dirty".For those wishing an even greater challenge there is the Insane difficulty with VERY resistant enemies and a core as fragile as cracked glass.Sanctum, where the simplest level can take 1 hour to complete.Every level can be VERY long. Even the first one can take anywhere between 30 minutes (if you are insanely fast) to 1 hours and a half and can last even longer. But don't worry: the Campaign has checkpoints between waves which you can also use to correct a mistake as long your have enough resources. It may sound cheap, but picking the "Load Checkpoint" will be something you'll do often here unless you feel there is no hope and click on the "Restart Level".The multiplayer option ramps this up by letting you set the game to 30 waves on any map, which easily means games going past 1 hour.Multiplayer Mayhem (Single if you must)The multiplayer in Sanctum is a bit different. Instead of a normal game with fixed waves every game on every map will have random enemies waves coming for you and your friends, that's right, no game will be quite the same and sometimes you'll be forced to change your tactics since the game can be downright mean sending airborne enemies and another wave of tricky enemies right away.You can also change how long the game will last: from 10 to 20 or even 30 waves, or an endless Survival mode, with increasingly stronger enemies, but with MUCH more resources than the normal, single player only, Campaign. This means more towers, faster weapon upgrades and more towers.Don't have friends that play Sanctum? Friends can't play right now? No problem. You can Host a game like this and play by yourself if you wish to, or leave open to friends (or other people) so they can join during it. You can also opt to play with people from the world but be warned: the Sanctum multiplayer is fairly dead and even on weekends it may be hard to get a lasting game with someone.Multiplayer has a few problems, though. Once you finish a map you are forced to create a new game and invite your friends again which doesn't sound bad, but gets annoying if you play with 2 or more people. It may be also a pet peeve mine, but you don't get levels achievements even if you do complete them with 30 waves setting, however you do keep progress from others like "Kill 4000 Runners"Music for your earsSanctum also has an amazing soundtrack, much more relaxing and soothing than what you'd expect for a game about killing hordes of enemies while hearing the heroine laughing and screaming in glee.For some the music will feel strangely out of place and annoying, for others it will be a contribution to immerse the player.Final notesThe game came out in 2011, and even on 2014 it remains one of the most pleasant, satisfactory games to play. Unfortunately Sanctum is often underrated and overlooked by people, sometimes because of its graphics and sometimes because it is a game that takes time to learn and it won't be afraid to slap you in the face quite often while you learn it.Sanctum is a game created with care and you can notice it as you play. Coffee Stain Studios did a good job with this game and it is worth your money and time. Even if you are not a fan of Tower Defense or First Person Shooter genres, give Sanctum a try at least in the demo, you may be surprised.

content:
Posted: April 9, 2014
												   If you are reading this review right now, and consider buying the game, do it. It's that simple, the game is totally worth the money. First of all, it's a First Person Shooter Tower Defense game. It's rules are simple:- Choose your personal Towers and Weapons.- Build blocks to create a maze as big as possible. - Build towers using resources that you gain for completing waves.- Upgrade your gear and towers.- Defend the core at all cost.   Sanctum has this good feeling of progression. Each new wave provides another, a more difficult challenge. And the player must keep up. By upgrading the towers and weapons. Which by the way, come in a surprisingly pleasant number. There are a lot of different towers to choose from. Some are used to deal damage to the creatures on the ground, and some to those airborn. So it's a good idea to buy them both, and experiment with their placement. Another very nice addition, are the "Support Towers". They can manipulate your enemies in various ways. The "Slow Field" for example, slows every creature that steps on the ground where it's placed. There also towers that amplify both yours and your tower's attacks, make your enemies more susceptible to damage, and so on. Speaking of enemies, each type of creature has it's own good looking alien body. That comes with a certain, sometimes hidden, area called the "Weakspot". Each alien has it's own unique abilities, like "Charging", "Soaking", "Dodging", well, you get the point. They not only behave differently, but also look so. Very cool and fantastic-looking models.   Your towers are the main source of firepower in Sanctum. But the player is as important. You get to choose from 6 unique weapons like the "Sniper", "Freeze",and "Tesla" guns. Which come in very handy when dealing with certain enemies. Especially those that somehow survived your defenses. You can create some really awesome guns and towers combinations if you think about it. You could, for example, use your "Freeze" gun to temporarily stun all the enemies in a certain radius. And then blow them all away with a charged "REX". It's really awesome come to think about it.   Another thing worth mentioning is the variety of maps (16 if have the DLCs) and game mods (like Bounty, Stamina, Pre-Build, and Standart). Which add a certain feeling of freedom. And the maps are pretty awesome. They look vibrant and alive, full of fauna and flora. Which is so strange looking that it makes you love it. Giant spores, glowing trees, multiple Suns, huge flowers, and mineral-rich caves. But the best thing about the maps, are the Easter Eggs. There are so many secret spots to find. So well-hidden and camouflaged, that you'll spend some time looking for them, and when you'll finally find them, they'll put a smile on that face.    And now, my favorite subject, the Music. I never thought I'd enjoy Sanctum's music so much as I do. Every map has 2 pieces of music attached to it. The first one plays in the "Building" phase. Usually a rather slow and tuneful loop, which I always like. And the second piece plays while the "Action" phase is in progress. A very pulsing, rhythmic and dynamic song, that I just love. Just listen to THIS or THIS. Please do, they might seem simple and plain, but they feel so complex and sparkling. 16 different maps, 2 songs for each... You do the math. All the credit goes to Coffee Stain Studios, and more specificaly to the genius Gustaf Tivander.   The last but not least, the best feature of this game is the Cooperative play. You and up to three of your friends get to build, upgrade and defend together. It's fun and effective, it grants even more creativity and firepower. Letting you get the most of this game. Which I strongly recommend if you're looking for either a good Co-op, or Tower Defense. 10/10

content:
Posted: November 18, 2013
												Short version: A big surprise. If you like tower defense at all and don't mind FPS, give it a shot. A great blend of strategy + action.Long version: Sanctum is great for TD fans that either like or don't mind some FPS action in their games. The two aspects blend together very well; on lower difficulties, one can pretty easily focus on one over the other and do fine, while on higher difficulties both are needed pretty equally. Additionally, there are towers that help your shots and a gun that helps your towers, ensuring that the two aren't just separate parts of the same game but actually integrated together.Even aside from FPS tactics, there's a fair amount more strategy than in most TD games, as the player must build a map for the enemies to travel on and building good maps can be necessary for survival. Building a map that makes enemies take longer to travel necessarily means less space for defensive towers, balancing the game with a choice of longer path or more firepower. And of course, correct positioning of towers for the most effective use of each one is as important as always in a TD game. Even the size of certain towers can be a strategic point for ensuring the player can move around flexibly.One can bring 3 different guns and up to 6 different towers to maps, ensuring many different ways to play the game, although the total number of guns and towers may be a bit low to take full advantage of that.If there's one problem I have with the game it's that some of the map designs come off as very lazy, but you'll largely forget about that when constructing a maze. I haven't played much multiplayer or survival mode myself, but in later waves of longer games, guns can also come to be seemingly ineffectual, as damage doesn't scale at all with the growing power of enemies. Sanctum does what it does near perfectly and there are very few changes I would consider making to improve it.

												It was the first time I played a "Hybrid" FPS/TD game and I have to say that I loved it.+ Very decent graphics.+ Every Turret and Weapon has upgrades.+ You can build mazes to make the enemy take longer routes.+ Full of "SECRETS" to discover (sometimes more than one per map).+ All enemy have a "weakspot" ( this makes some turrets stronger for each kind of monster, also makes you aim at specific parts of the monsters).+ Very challenging. Try the insane dificulty :O- Sometimes it gets boring when maps take +45minutes to beat all waves or you have a nice Turret and maze combination built to do most of your work.- Multiplayer has almost no players. (Never seen more than 7 players online).- There is a buggy achievement. (Takes forever to get it, even though it's one of the easiest)- You will probably need some guides to find all the secrets because they are extremely hard to find on your own. ( I used guides for most of them :$).It gave me some good hours of fun and I can't wait to start playing Sanctum 2.Remember this is just my opinion, some of my (+) can be a (-) to you and viceversa. It depends from player to player.Also I'm sorry for my English. (I'm Portuguese).Hope my review was helpful to you! :D

content:
Posted: October 2, 2015
												Sanctum is a Tower Defense game which allows for a first person shooter perspective. Released in 2011, graphically it doesn't look bad at all. The object of the game is to lay blocks and outfit them with varying weaponry to direct the path of your enemy waves, lay down suppressive fire and take out as many enemies as possible, and have a varied amount of weapons as each wave has different enemies who have resistences to certain types of damage. Once you have done this, you go into initiate a wave, use your own personal first person shooter weapons and assist the towers with defeating waves before they reach your core. At the end of each wave you are given a number of resources which can be spent on upgrades both to the towers as well as your personal weapons. I've played several tower defense games, but this one let's you get down in there and add a personal touch to defense, by combining the FPS experience with more traditional tower defense features. While I enjoyed Sanctum, I look forward to seeing what happens next in the series and how they upgrade our experience to another level. Sanctum features single player mode, a variety of different levels each with their own geography and challenges, as well as multiplayer mode. I recommend going through the tutorial phase, so you really get an understanding of what the weapons and enemies are capable of before diving right into the main game.

content:
Posted: June 17, 2016
												Although I am writing this having played the sequel, Sanctum 2, I'm still going to recommend it. In fact, I'm recommending you to get both Sanctum and Sanctum 2. Get this: Sanctum and Sanctum 2, although not entirely different games, play different altogether. Read my review on Sanctum 2 for additional details.Simply put, Sanctum puts more emphasis on maze and tower building, and has slightly less player interaction (e.g. you cannot change towers' targeting behavior) compared to Sanctum 2. I would say Sanctum is 90% tower defense and 10% hero defense, although based on many other players' calculations, and also depending on which stage you're playing, it could be classified as 75% tower defense and 25% hero defense. The hero defense number can be further increased if players themselves choose to actively participate in fights against enemies. In short, however, it is safe to say that there are more times in Sanctum when you can just leave your towers alone to do the defense than in Sanctum 2.Gameplay aside, Sanctum is easily way ahead of its time for a game that was released in 2011. The graphics are impressive, and the developers spot-on exploited their advantage by designing an original world that is both beautiful and immersive. With its original characters and concepts, Sanctum deserves a whole lot more love than it currently does and that is doing it no justice.Sanctum is a jewel of a game, a world record that has only been beaten by its sequel, which sadly had been born and crafted at the wrong time: Valve's own Portal 2 was released merely days later and everybody boarded the hype train for the more famous franchise. Sanctum, having barely wrestled gamers' attention from bigger titles such as Crysis 2, Dragon Age 2 and the PC release of Assassin's Creed: Brotherhood earlier that year, took a hit to its sales that persisted throughout 2011's Steam Summer Sale. Later that year, releases of games such as Dead Island, Dungeon Siege 3 and The Witcher 2: Assassins of Kings kept Sanctum from floating above the surface, while it struggled to race for sales before FPS competitors Battlefield 3 and Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3 joined in for their share. However, it was when The Elder Scrolls 5: Skyrim was released in November that Sanctum drowned among the hype.But is Sanctum dead? No, far from it. Like a ship filled with treasures, it had just sunk to the ocean floor, waiting for ambitious adventurers to come and retrieve it, and those who are looking for glorious gold would do well to pick it up. And good treasures should always be shared, and spent together. You can spread the word about the treasures to people you know, or pick up additional treasures to be given to them. Either way is a bargain for you as long as you are in possession of such a valuable artifact.The paragon of Sanctum is the soundtrack. Perfectly composed to perfectly match the environment and mood, not many music composition can reach out to player's emotions as effectively as Sanctum. When you're done listening to the main menu theme on repeated loops while you sleep, play it one more time while you read the 2 or 3 paragraphs above. Leave a comment if you shed a tear or 2.This game is easily, a10 out of 10

content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
Story/Presentation: 8Not much to say about this game's story, really. It's really just about a girl who defends a major core built from her allies from aliens invading. It's basic, but what I gotta give an above average score is it's presentation. First, the aliens. They look so cool! They're all very distinctive and unique in their own design and traits, and works perfectly with the game's tone. The soundtrack of the game's Really lovely and engaging as well. I loved and was happy buying it's soundtrack after trying out the game. Gameplay: 10This is the highlight of the game and what makes it SO good~! The game is one of the world's first First Person Shooter Tower of Defence. The design behind it and the strategy one has to make is perfect. The majority of the weapons are awesome, and it all plays good roles to strategize on how to defeat the aliens from reaching the core. Keep in mind that the game's Very hard, and takes a lot of practice to get it going, but still worth it. I feel like the combat was very balanced. With the constant reloads your own weapon has, it gives good opportunity for your towers to fight and cover for you.Overall: 9It's very obvious this game can't be for everyone, but it's still incredibly addicting. I am extremely happy I gave this game a try. It's super memorable, it's tons of fun, very challenging, and provides great replay value. It's a shame it's not that well played much since the release of it's sequel title, for I'd love to try out the Co-Op version of this at some point, but doesn't stop me from trying the game again in single player and play it more often. I would HIGHLY recommend this game for anybody.

content:
Posted: May 9, 2016
												Short Version:Like TDs? Definitely give this one a spin unless you heavily dislike FSPs.Long Version:Gameplay - The hybrid tower/FPS feels very good as you can single handedly wipe the some mobs yourself, let the towers do it for yourself or fine tune your defence in order to covers each's sides flaws or create true deathzones. There's a very decent number of maps with varied layouts and the possibilty to maze in your own style. Your typical towers/weapons are here with a few more original concepts in between. The difficulty feels fair, it takes good tower strategy and shooting in order to clear the more difficult maps. Multiplayer is there too and I had great fun playing with some friends, too bad they can't help you tackle the Insane difficulty ones so I could get those achievements T_T.Story - Not much of it at first glance, there's material outside the game and some secrets to be found in some maps but overall it's not the selling point. It would eventually get greatly expanded in Sanctum 2 but I'll comment on that on it's review.Sound - I surprinsingly love this game's tunes, I often listen to game ST's outside and people give me the looks but, listen to Sanctum's, and they praise it, they can't believe it's from a game, it's a different style. (Which I would love more of, if anyone know' more stuff like this PM me or something, I couldn't find more work by the same guy).Graphics - The looks fit the futuristic style and everything is clean and slick. I personally tone some of it down because all the bloom and stuff makes the game so bright and vividly coloured it hurts my eyes but that's my preference.

content:
Posted: December 17, 2014
												A great TD game - better than Sanctum 2. It's cheap, runs well, looks pretty. FPS play works very well in the game to keep the action going.It's also very cool to play with other people, I've gone hours on survival mode with my friends.The game has a lot of content going for it already, but then there's also the free DLCs and the really cheap ones (they go down to $0.99 on sale).I find the game is better than Sanctum 2 - the game just feels better. It really has polish, and I felt Sanctum 2 kind of lacked that; as a result, it's a funner game. You don't have to level up for perks, (the grind is removed entirely) and there isn't pressure to be constantly firing at all times.I also see much better FPS in this game than in Sanctum 2, even when I turn down the graphics to low. The game ends up looking worse than Sanctum 1 but still doesn't run as well.There are a lot of really cool towers in this game too, and the lack of a wall limit (which was an odd decision for Sanctum 2 that further distanced it from a TD game) lets you be much more inventive with the game.Past that, Sanctum is really a good game. For fans of TD, FPS, and messing around with their friends, Sanctum is a game for you.

												This game has a ton of updates and new free stuff added every couple months. It also has AAA graphics and co-op or single-user game play for the price of an indie puzzle game -- on sale. Lots of replayability on the few maps it comes with, and (though somewhat controversial) the new maps and weapons released as DLC are a lot of fresh fun that I feel are worth the cost. The DLC weapons can be used by you in games that your friends may not have them, which helps keep your load outs unique to eachother, and they're cheap if you ever want to add on. Those complaining of this model are forgetting how much replayable game you are already getting for the base price of 9.99. The extra stuff is just sprinkles and doughnuts. Play it with your friends or alone, it's a great mesh of tower defense and varied, upgradable gunplay. Simply stunning game.

content:
Posted: January 15, 2015
												Sanctum is a fun and challenging game. It requires you to balance resources and defense structures. The goal of each map is to defend a core from incoming waves of monsters. Simple right? It's not. Each wave is unique in that the content varies. Some waves may only contain one monster, while another wave can contain many types. Each monster has a specific weak spot that you target to kill them more effectively. You have to destoy these waves by constructing an efficient maze of towers and guns. But you don't have unlimited resources; only what is given to you after each wave. That's when creativity and balancing come into play.The game is even more fun under mulitplayer mode. With more people, you have more resources to spend to defend your core. However, the monster waves are random and stronger than the single player version. Communication is key to having a sucessful game. A method that can be used have each person focus on a type of tower (one person can focus on anti-air and floors, while another one could focus on ground and laser towers)This game was worth the purchase. It provides you with a great challenge. Be warned though because each round can take up to an hour or more. If you have plenty of time to kill and want a challenge, then this game is for you. But if you don't have the time or patience to play, skip this game. There will be times where after playing for 45 minutest to an hour, you find out that your core has been attacked and you no longer have that 100%. You quit and then you resume from last save. So have paitence when playing this game. One last note: Play around with the multiplayer chat. You'll be laughing a lot.

Not only that - the way that it beutifully satisfies the different types of players in Co-op means (outside of Portal 2), its the game you have to have as a co-op. I would like to see some more maps, but with Sanctum 2 here - Im thinking this is not something I am ever likely to see. But, counterbalance this with what is now a very reasonable price, and you've got yourself a highly enjoyable game thats worth the spend when your looking to share your evenings with that special IP address.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2016
												I can recommend this game, but just barely. If you have time to play either Sanctum or Sanctum 2, please opt for the second in the series. The real issue with the original Sanctum, in my view, is just that there are just too many variables.  Sanctum is the free jazz of FPS tower defense, for my music fans out there. In the second game, your weapon stays the same, you can drop around 15 towers per map, and each tower can be upgraded 3 times. In Sanctum, you can upgrade your weapon up to 5 times, you can upgrade towers up to 5 times, and you can drop as many towers as you can afford. Secondly, the waves you fight each time you play a map are random. This led both me and my partner to fail maps repeatedly without really getting a feel for what our issues were. We completed all main game and DLC maps on normal, but had an extremely difficult time with a few on hard. An important aspect of any game is the sense of feedback the player is given. I feel that almost all of the changes made in the second game were positive. However, FPS tower defense is a unique and awesome genre, and the importance placed both on towers and the player's ability to place shots makes this series more engaging than typical tower defense.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												I enjoyed this one quite a bit.  Many if not most games I've played that try to mix tower defense with a controllable character fall flat because the balance doesn't work.  In this one, though, you can't only focus on one aspect.  If you just level up your weapons a ton, you'll run up against cooldowns and ammo restrictions and never be able to gun down all the enemies yourself.  If you only build towers and try to take a smoke break during the level, you'll be overrun during waves that have skill-dependent enemies.  The inclusion of enemies with a weak point that the player can aim for, but the towers won't, is an inspired choice.  It forces you to build and act in concert with your defenses.  Tough enemies can be slowed down, things that are only vulnerable in a single spot can be sniped, and swarms can be intelligently targeted with AOE attacks.  The sole drawback is that you can only hold 3 guns, and the sniper rifle and cold gun seem, to me, indispensable.  The other complaint I can make is that the 3-D nature of the game isn't fully supported/exploited.  So, unlike most TD games, a tower can't just shoot anything in its 'range'.  It has to have line-of-sight (in most cases).  This is good, as it forces you to think about where to put your blocks, which ones to make shot-transparent, and what obstacles in the level will affect your fields of fire. It's bad, though, because the game will show you a circle on the overhead view that denotes the tower's max range, but nothing else.  If you want to learn what it can actually see, the only solutions are to put your character's perspective as close as you can to the tower's (usually impossible, since you can't stand inside it, and the towers are mostly a lot taller than your PC) or observe what it shoots at during the levels (which requires you to look carefully at the overview while the action's going on, and not participate in the defense).  A feature that gave you the POV of the tower would make this so much easier.Of note, this recommendation includes the free add-ons unlocking new towers and weapons, as well as the paid-for DLC granting new maps.  This adds much-needed variety, and I would probably be less enthusiastic if I'd played it at release.

content:
Posted: April 25, 2011
												Sanctum is a welcome twist on the Tower Defense ("TD") genre. In Sanctum, you roam the map, FPS-style, adding your own firepower against the invaders. You can choose to upgrade your personal firepower in the same way you upgrade your towers. The most useful mindset is to think of yourself as a mobile tower that augments your fixed towers. Along with the usual kill pits you build in TD games, you'll find yourself creating several kill corridors -- straight walkways that you can pearch at the end of and get maximum use out of your personal weaponry.At release there are are only 3 maps, but more are promised. 4-6 hours of entertainment, playing once through. More maps will help this game.You can play mutliplayer, too.I give Sanctum a recommendation to fans of TD. Others should probably start with a more traditional TD game like Defense Grid, which offers more maps, more polish, and a better all-around value. Still, Sanctum is worth a look. Watch for the promised extra content.

content:
Posted: January 5, 2016
												This game is great for two player co-op.  It's more strategic and less furious action than team shooter games, so, I find, it is good for couples co-op play (husband and wife, or boyfriend and girlfriend).  The game has action, with your character shooting down the incoming aliens, and also strategy, with your team building a maze of defensive towers and choosing which kind of towers.  The goal of the game is stop the aliens from destroying your core (home base building).  I find this can be a more satisfying, constructive goal than a goal of simply killing aliens (or killing other players).  The game is nicely implemented and fun to play, as is its sequel.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 13
												Sanctum is a strategy/FPS hybrid game with tower defense tied in, complimented by its exciting and catchy sci-fi soundtrack and awesome environments. In Sanctum, you play as a soldier known as Autumn Skye, and you must defend The Core, the power source for all of your towers and for your entire base. Aliens of different forms will come and attempt to attack it, and attack you and your friends. Each enemy has different strategies of attacking, and each one has different weak-spots, where hits will do more damage than the hits would on the other parts of their bodies. Some of these enemies are airborne, and will attack from above, and some will attack ground-level.There are 16 maps in the base-game Sanctum, and each have different amounts of space for your tower bases. You can arrange them however you like, and you and your friends must build a maze to make it so that the aliens, known as the Lumes, will have the hardest time possible attempting their reach to your Core. You must use your resources to build new towers, upgrade old towers, and upgrade your weapons.Sanctum is a fun game to play with friends, or in single-player alike, and the variation to the enemies, weapons, and towers is pretty cool. I would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys strategy games, FPS games, and tower defense games, as well as those who like sci-fi themes. ^.^

number of helpful: 17 of 31 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 12, 2014
												Let me start by saying that I do not recommend this game at its full price. I paid .99 USD for it so for that price you cant really go too wrong. I enjoyed the game at first, its uniqu(ish) blend of FPS and TD was amusing, but I soon started to see that the game was lacking in some areas. I played with a friend as well to see what how he felt about and found us agreeing in most areas. My biggest griped was polish. The game seems like it coulda used a decent amount it. I noticed animations gliching out a bunch of times, turrets having fits when enemies quickly moved in and out of range, the player often getting stuck and needing to teleport out (seems like a copout from a dev standpoint). My friends biggest gripe was odd balancing. We often found that the first 4-6 waves of enemies we could stop before they barely made any progress out of the starting point, then the next wave would break right through to the end and we'd loose. Easy, easy, easy, easy, easy, insanely hard. Not a fun difficutly curve. Also, while the fps portions of the game all worked nicely and looked good, the TD portions seemed ad hoc assembly of tower defense features that didnt fit together to well anf felt clunky. Like the game was designed as a FPS defense kinda thing, then someone added in the the tower stuff where ever it would fit. That being said if you love FPSs and are so so about TDs, then this might just be for you! But if you love TDs and could take or leave a FPS, then this isnt going to mesh well. Its not a bad game, and Im sure there are lots of people who love it. But, it wanst my cup of tea. To me it felt like 2/10 TD and 8/10 FPS, where a smash hit in my eyes would have those numbers transposed. Over all i would give it a 6 out of 10. Not bad, but not good enough to keep me coming back for more.

												*INITIAL IMPRESSIONS*Of course I start getting into it now that the sequel dwells on the horizon. FML.Pretty much Sanctum is a tower defense game, you fight off a wave then you're given time to build up defences and upgrade your towers and weapons in anticipation of what the next wave will contain. Not to say that Sanctum is bland though, personally I like it a helluva lot more than the other TD game I've played, the kills felt rewarding, the challenge curve is rock steady and the game has changeable loadouts for weapons and towers to increase variety and to make room for countless strategies and combinations of defenses. You like running-and-gunning? Well you can! Just upgrade your weapons more than your towers and blast away! ORYou like strategic placements of towers so that they can lay a rain of pain as efficiently as possible? You can! Just build more towers and upgrade as much as your "money" or "Resource". 9/10 for trying out this completely new idea and actually making it work.

Posted: November 10, 2011
												Picked this game up on a recommendation from EnPfhy.  This is a TON of fun.  It combines all the aspects of a great tower defence game with the ability to be on the ground fighting and shooting along with your towers.  You can upgrade both your towers and your personal weapons, and there is co-op play for up to four people.  There are so many ways to approach any map, and the attacking armies are randomized so that every playthrough is different.  The DLC is not necessary (although the violator is a very useful tower to own), and the price is great for the amount of gameplay that you get.  Highly recommended.

Posted: May 5, 2012
												An FPS tower defense game, removing my biggest complaint about the genre: Feeling hopeless as a drifting cursor around the map. Aesthetically it feels very similar to Unreal Tournament 3 [It feels like it was influenced by Japanese culture], just using a brighter palette than UT3.Gameplay wise, you plot out where you want the enemies to go by building blocks and creating tunnels to funnel the enemy to the path of the Core, which you're defending. Each block can be upgraded to hold a gatling gun, scattering laser [Attacks ground + air enemies], lightning bolt [which takes a bit to charge but will do massive damage], and a dozen other weapons + DLC weapons. Each individual unit is upgradeable [including the guns you bring on your character] and deciding on what to upgrade between waves is important, as each wave throws a different setup of enemies at you, which it will tell you on the bottom left before starting.Whether at full price or on sale, this game is a steal.

Posted: October 17, 2012
												I'm not someone that likes tower defense games very much. Now, that's saying something because I enjoy playing this game. It's not the typical td game, where it tells you "here's a place you can build... make... tch, I don't care". This game has a grid layout on (typically) a large portion of the map. It is your choice where to place blocks, how to change the enemy travel path, where to put weapons, where to put special floor tiles, even upgrading your guns. If you like td games, you should love this. This was definitely worth the price during the sale, I regret nothing!

Posted: December 31, 2013
												Sanctum does an excellent job of balancing fast-paced FPS action with building strategic tower defense. If you have played dungeon defenders it is somewhat similar although Sanctum is first-person and has no character classes. However, you do get several weapons to choose from before each map and you can generally bring about 3 along with you. Even better, you get to choose about 5-8 types of towers to take along as well and so there is a lot of flexibility in how you want to set up your defenses. Plus if you have a friend who will play then that's more hours of fun right there.

Posted: December 19, 2011
												A brilliant mix of well-executed tower defense and intense, tactical first person shooting, this game has been my greatest pleasant surprise of 2011. Play consists of building phases (where you construct your maze and populate it with a variety of weapons) and action phases (where the aliens come, your towers to their work, and you clean up/cover your♥♥♥♥♥fall off the side of the map uselessly). It's well paced, strategically substantial during the build phases, and absolutely frenetic during the action phases. For its asking price, I can't recommend this thing highly enough. The DLC is generally well done as well, and helps support a tiny developer with enormous potential.

Posted: March 4, 2012
												Keeps the good parts of tower defence: a range of mobs, towers, and debuffs that invite tactical consideration, and the oft-missed maze-building on most maps; but then adds to that a surprisingly fluid rocket-jumping FPS to let you pick off or crack the shield of troublemakers while the towers do their thing. The Violator DLC is lovely, the mazebuilding maps are good, but the others are mostly forgettable and it cries out for third-party map support (or just more maps) rather than the sequel it's getting.

												I'll make this short, It's a great...no FANTASTIC game if you enjoy strategy/tower defence games. Sanctum's controls and mechanics are easy to pick up. content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												Sanctum is a fun and challenging game. It requires you to balance resources and defense structures. The goal of each map is to defend a core from incoming waves of monsters. Simple right? It's not. Each wave is unique in that the content varies. Some waves may only contain one monster, while another wave can contain many types. Each monster has a specific weak spot that you target to kill them more effectively.  You have to destoy these waves by constructing an efficient maze of towers and guns. But you don't have unlimited resources; only what is given to you after each wave. That's when creativity and balancing come into play.The game is even more fun under mulitplayer mode. With more people, you have more resources to spend to defend your core. However, the monster waves are random and stronger than the single player  version. Communication is key to having a sucessful game. A method that can be used have each person focus on a type of tower (one person can focus on anti-air and floors, while another one could focus on ground and laser towers)This game was worth the purchase. It provides you with a great challenge. Be warned though because each round can take up to an hour or more. If you have plenty of time to kill and want a challenge, then this game is for you. But if you don't have the time or patience to play, skip this game. There will be times where after playing for 45 minutest to an hour, you find out that your core has been attacked and you no longer have that 100%. You quit and then you resume from last save. So have paitence when playing this game. One last note: Play around with the multiplayer chat. You'll be laughing a lot.

Posted: July 29, 2012
												Sanctum is a hybrid FPS tower defence game. Build and upgrade your towers between waves, and then assist your towers with killing the invaders before they destroy your base power core. The combat feels like a fast paced old school FPS. The two elements fit together nicely, for example some enemies take reduced damage from  towers until the player shoots their weak spot. And of course each different tower is better suited to killing different types of enemies. The environment can be a hazard to the player - fall off a ledge and enemies will push forward until you recover. This all allows for some varied and deep tactics. The number of maps, difficulty levels and achievements provides for many hours of replayability. The graphics and sound quality is good for an indie release, and the game is also very stable and bug free. The only major flaw is the lack of any kind of story to tie the levels together. But Sanctum is still great value for money, even at full price.

Posted: August 17, 2014
												Have friends who enjoy teamwork? Then look at this game. You will have a good laugh playing this together as you need to plan ahead in each level how to beat the waves of enemies attacking. Plan the route, plan towers and uppgrades etc.Gfx, Gameplay, Sfx and music is great. I must say that the soundtrack is spot on to the atmosphere. The game is easy to understand but hard to master.Level upp your characters and there abillities, perks and weapons. Unlock more advanced towers. Most of all, have fun... ;)This is the first of the series of Sanctum. And i can promise that you will enjoy this if you enjoyed Sanctum 2.

Posted: November 4, 2011
												Despite the fact that it has weapons pack DLC and map pack DLC (both of which are paid) it is a surprisingly fun game.  The weapon DLC is not pay-to-win (thankfully) but instead just gives you more flexibility for playstyle.  It's a tower-defense game, you can place blocks to adjust enemy movement, put towers on them, said towers can be upgraded.Fairly simple style, and very fun.  I played for 100 minutes my first playthrough, and that was only 2 levels!  There's no character customization (unfortunately) so you're stuck as the red-head you see in the banner.  You unlock more towers as you play through (maybe more weapons, I hadn't found more yet) which gives you more variety, and the enemies are VERY varied and specialist.  One will run incredibly fast if given a straight sprint, but slows to a crawl around corners.  Another can only be damaged by shooting it in the back of the head.7/10 And thanks to my friend Erythrocytes for gifting me this.

Posted: July 17, 2011
												Lets begin by saying this game is a great concept and reminds me of some custom maps in Starcraft 2 for tower defense. The difference here is the game is extremely polished, and plays relatively straight forward, I can't really elaborate since it simply provides tower defense (contruction) with hero combat (FPS). The only real flaw I can find in this game for what it is, is the forced heavy use of the FPS component (upgrading assault is pretty much necessary, and takes priority over such things as mazing, investing in tower combos). Great game and great price too, a definite recommendation.

Posted: November 28, 2012
												Sanctum artfully blends strategy and FPS to create an interesting take on the tower defense experience. The game mechanics are surprisingly well-thought out, suited to provide challenges to the experts and novices of both of these genres. The multiplayer is tons of fun, the graphics allow for smooth visuals without sacrificing smooth performance, and best of all, it doesn't come with a ridiculous $60 price tag. Honestly, the only problem I found with this game is the lack of built-in voice chat capability, and I'm sure if people make enough of a stink about it, they might convince the developer to add that in the next update.I'd definitely give this one a shot, especially if you've got people to play co-op with or are just looking for some fresh, captivating entertainment.

												Adds a flare to the tower defense genre by introducing first person game mechanics.  These include first person placement and upgrading of towers and first person shooting.  Unreal based graphics engine looks sharp and polished.  Your weapons can be upgraded in lieu of tower defenses.  Tower foundations can be fitted with teleporters allowing quick access to different parts of the map.  Well thoughtout and executed.  Only 4 maps at present but multiple difficulties.  A steal for the summer sale price.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2016
												Sanctum is an interesting game to talk about. A lot of times when you ask someone if they like tower defense style games, you generally always get an answer to where they find it either good or just boring. On the other hand, asking if someone likes first person shooters, a lot of people will normally say yes depending on which part of the genre you're talking about. Sanctum is a different beast, it combines best of both worlds to make for an interesting concept. Being one or few of the only games that utilizes a hybrid tower defense/first person shooter approach, it excutes the idea in a very balanced fashion. Albeit, the amount of levels without dlc is rather short, with it, there is enough variety both gameplay wise and level wise there to give you several hours of gameplay alone or with your friends. Did I mention you can play with your friends? Thought I didn't.Overall, good game, good idea, just a little short, but still worthy of playing if you like to have something to play for a few hours, not including the well hidden secrets that can keep you going a little while longer.I suggest buying this during a sale if possible however, as you'll want the dlcs that comes with this. Except for Yogscave, we don't talk about Yogscave.7/10

content:
Posted: October 3, 2015
												Before I picked up first Sanctum game I already played Sanctum 2. Why? To be honest, I didn't expected much for this kind mix of genres and since I got it from some bundle I didn't really care about previous game. I enjoyed Sanctum 2 so I decided to get first one on next sale. I don't regret it. People complain that there aren't mapy maps - don't forget about difficult levels. I don't think number of maps are important in this kind of games. Many years ago, when Flash Element TD was created, there was only one map but many people enjoyed it for hundreds of hours. Still, there is some variety, so it's not like you don't have any choice at all. Sadly, maybe for me, the number of towers you will be using are very low... maybe I just found out a great tactic so I wasn't in need to use others than 2 or 3. Same goes for weapons - sniper and rocket launcher will alone make you powerful to depend less on towers. Maybe it's because I already had some experience from Sanctum 2, but the difficult level, even the hardest one, was surely more easier than those in second Sanctum game. Still, it can be a really nice challenge for people who enjoys all kind of Tower Defense games. And I recommend even this strange, but very fun, mix. I had really good time playing it and maybe some day I will want to play it once again. Just be sure to have some friends if you want to have fun online, since there aren't many active players.

content:
Posted: July 20, 2015
												Personal Rating: 5 of 10First Person Shooter with Tower Defense. One of the most looked forward to game but turns out to be rather dissapointing. The game is nice and idea is fresh but this game is not meant to be played alone as it turns out to be a chore. Many tower defense game give you a nice progress with difficulty level scaled to increase in a comfortable manner. This game scale them from 0 to 10 in 3 levels. Before every wave begins, you are allowed to place towers, teleporters, traps, blockage or upgrade your weapon. But first person building is rather redundant and inefficient since you need to keep track on where you are and where you are building. A top down interface to construct tower would be nice since you cannot even do upgrades or construction during a wave. I tried upgrading my weapon and placing some blockade to extend the route. 1st wave seemed easy, 2nd was fine since I upgraded my weapon and so was the 3rd wave. Then came the 4th wave and I can't even kill 25% off them. So all you do is chase the enemies through the maze you plot and fire at will. Not many strategic play involved unless during between waves.This game is clearly made for multiplayer but since its considered outdated, there aren't anyone to play with at all. If you have friends or siblings to play with then this could be fun.

content:
Posted: December 7, 2016
												it's a good game if you pick it up for free but not really worth paying much money for. There just isn't enough her to keep you entertained for long. place turret then shoot place turrets then shoot, rinse and repeat. that being said, if there was time and money spent developing the idea then it could be really good. It's just the lack of that hold it back, like every death animation is the same, every effect is the same, there are a very limited amount of weapons that you can have and your just best off maxing out the sniper rifle and spending the rest onn turrets. wich kind of takes most of the stratergy out of the game. it can be fun for the first few hours but soon you realise that your main job is to attack targets the turrets can't shoot. mainly it's just the lack of variety that lets this game down. It actually reminds me a lot of early 1990's titles like battlezone where they where limited by what a computer can do except in terms of how many units spawn. clearly someone worked really hard but they where mainly alone in their endevors and had extreme budget limitations. worth playing but doesn't have a long lasting playability.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 26, 2015
												This review originally written on June 18, 2012 on GameFAQs"A unique tower defense and FPS hybrid worthy of your time."Sanctum is a tower defense game at its heart. You build towers and create mazes to stop the waves of enemies. All of this is in done in first person and when the wave starts you can use your 3 guns to personally attack the enemies. As the developers have said this is the first game ever to have this combination and it sure is fun!GRAPHICS: 10/10The graphics are pretty good all around. It can be taxing on older computers so it should be noted that the developers have thoughtfully allowed you to edit the engine files to reduce the graphics even further. To me this is a huge plus because if I couldn't do that I couldn't play this game. My only complaint is that the lower your resolution the fuzzier the text gets. I can barely read it at 800x600. The higher your resolution the harder the game is on your computer. That said this game lets you go down all the way to 320x200! So if your computer is real bad you can turn the resolution down that far and play with ease when you start the wave, then turn it up in between waves to build.SOUND: 9/10There are some nice sound effects when you build and do things like that. The gun sounds are kind of lackluster but this isn't heavily focused on that. Nothing bad about the monster sounds either. The music is actually really good and doesn't get repetitive or annoying.STORYNo score because there isn't a story and tower defense games don't necessarily need one. I think they have released some lore and stuff in preparation for the sequel but I haven't read any of it. All I know is that you're a girl and you have something on your left arm that allows you to build towers. Your goal is to stop the invading monsters from getting to the giant blue core. What that core is I don't know.TOWER DEFENSE ASPECT: 10/10As I said this game is tower defense at its heart and it does not disappoint. There are several tower types, all useful to varying degrees depending on your play style. Something this game does that sadly few TDs do is allowing you to build a maze that the enemies are forced to run through. This allows for even more strategy than just simply building at certain spots outside of the enemies' route. On most maps you can create their route! You also have a set amount of towers equipped that you can then use to build on the level. This means even more strategy.FIRST PERSON SHOOTER ASPECT: 9/10This game is a shooter at a distant second. When you manually start the next wave of enemies you can then shoot them with your own weapons which you choose before the level starts. This part of the game is pretty basic as expected. The weapons are simple but each one does have an alternate fire which adds more variety. You can also upgrade them with your money to make them stronger. Despite shooting not being the main focus it's still essential for beating the levels.What gives this a 9/10 instead of something lower is the fact that all enemies have a weak spot that can be exploited by you for a great increase in damage. Further, some enemies can only be killed by hitting them in their weak spot, something that isn't easy for your towers. There is an enemy that can only be hurt from its back. A tall enemy with a bobbing head that only takes damage from attacks to its head. Still another that has armor that greatly reduces damage to it and the only way to temporarily remove the armor is for a single concentrated shot (sniper) to hit it in the head. All this means a lot more strategy and player input is required than just simply shooting the enemy. Unfortunately if you have horrendous aiming skills you may have trouble, but there is an easy difficulty for you to enjoy.ENEMIES: 9/10There are more enemy types than the ones listed above, and they're all distinct. There are also flying enemies which pay no heed to your carefully made mazes. The designs are unique and interesting and follow a similar theme.LENGTH AND REPLAYABILITYThere are several maps to enjoy including a few free ones and others you must pay for (worth it). Each map has 4 difficulties as well as various survival modes to play. On normal a map will take an hour or so to beat. There is also multiplayer but I never messed with that.FINAL SCORE: 9/10This is a must play for any fan of tower defense, if only to check out something new and unique in the genre. Even if you aren't into TDs check this game out (so long as you at least like FPSs) and who knows it just might get you into the genre. I got this game on a sale and it's worth it even at full price. There is a demo so if you aren't sure give it a spin.

content:
Posted: July 31, 2013
												An absolutely stunningly well-made blend of First-Person Shooter and Tower Defence. The level designs are breathtaking, the music gives you chills, and it makes for a very enjoyable game experience. However, to refrain from stress-induced rage I highly recommend sticking to the lower difficulties, I found even 'Normal' difficulty to be a painful, frustrating, repetitive slog towards the later waves. So let it never be said this game doesn't challenge you. It tests your gaming ability, your strategic thinking, and your level of sanity, as you may very well end up picking up the monitor and hurling it through a wall by the end of it.

content:
Posted: April 9, 2011
												Sanctum is a First-Person Shooter mixed with a Tower Defense. The aim of the game is to prevent the swarm from reaching the core. You can do this by building blocks which can be used to create your maze, which can also be upgraded to a various number of defense towers which can blast the living sh*t out of the swarm. Along with that, you can use your weapons to shoot at the swarm whilst moving around. This is definitely a unique game, as I believe it to be the first of its kind.

Worth picking up with a friend but solo it won't last you very long unless you're a die-hard Tower Defense fan.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2012
												If you like Tower Defense games, this is one game for you.You control one builder, FPS, and swap between building tower or upgrading weapons mode. You need also to build blocks to maze enemies. Your job is to stop them from reaching the destination, by blocking their paths and shooting them down yourself with your towers to support you.Once you complete building phase, you enter combat phase. A series of mob will come from one point to another point at the end of the map. Prevent them.Combat system is flawless, you can move freely from point to point, or teleport instantly to where the system allows. This gives freedom and more strategies when combating enemies.Minus point, too few maps to play in. Extra maps require you to purchase DLCs,

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												Where to begin? Okay simply put: Do you like tower defense?, DO you enjoy Strategy? Do you ENjoy FPS's? Do you enjoy CHallenge? If you answered yest to 2 more more of those questions, you'll enjoy this game.This game is fun, fast paced and almost insanely challenging, but it makes wining the statges that much more rewarding. It's not just about placing your turrents it's about placing those turrets and emptying a full salvo from your rocket launcher at anyone unfortunate enough to survive your tower maze of doom!There is no greater joy that to see a battered giant on his last bit of health as he rounds the final corner and limps out of the death mage and straight into the crosshairs of your sniper rifle.

content:
Posted: January 27
Product received for free
												I got this game from a Humble Bundle pack. Not entirely free, but for practical purposes you could say so.From an aesthetics and design perspective, this game is top notch. It also has a decent kind of humour in it that I enjoy. None-the-less the FPS facet of this game is quite lacking. For the sake of a functional tower defense game the enemies must travel in very specific ways with very predictable behaviour and that is as good for an FPS as the ducks in Duck Hunt. Anyone who knows what's he/she's doing will be able to emplace a couple of guns at the enemies' spawn point, then make a tight corridor with Amp Fields and Holo-blocks (bullet damage multipliers) and just sit at the end of the corridor holding the mouse button. The gun overheated? No problem! swap to the Sniper rifle and click instead of holding. That run out too? switch back! Needless to say that the protagonist sounds way more into that than me.In case you're in doubt, yes, there's no ammo count in this game. The sniper rifle and shotgun have between 1 and 6 shots, all other guns are based on "overheating".If you like either fishing or tower defense games, you might like this one. If you want a solo or co-op game to shoot at waves of monsters which can actually react to you and give you action, then pick Killing Floor 2 instead.

number of helpful: 1 of 6 people (17%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 6, 2016
												Came in looking for the Tower Defense style of games, and was intrigued by the addition of the FPS-style. I think it was fun to pop in and play for a little while, but the old feel of Warcraft 3-era Tower Defense Mods I was looking for was lost since I only got the chance to play by myself. I found myself mainly booting it up for a few waves while waiting for friends to sign online to play other games. Would be great as a tablet game to play on train/plane rides, but I don't think I'd sit down and dedicate long stretches of time to just Sanctum.I think if you're looking at it from a fresh perspective, go ahead and give it a whirl. If you're looking for something like a Green TD, Wintermaul style of game though, I would give it a pass since it doesn't compare to those game's play style.

content:
Posted: January 24, 2014
												The game felt very lonley. It lacked a story and while it may have been better had I played multiplayer it felt really empty on single player. So much so that I really didn't want to continue. I did notice a bigger focus on weapons rather than towers. I always got better results by making simple mazes and then focusing my income on improving weapons instead of towers. Unfotunitly there's a build phase and an enemy phase. So you can't build on the fly like most tower defense games. Because of that you can't fix mistakes you may have made or improve as needed like other tower defense games and because of that I felt very restricted. Again it was make maze shoot with gun. It just couldn't keep my interest in comparison to other tower games like Defense Grid or Orcs must die.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2013
												Pre-Word: I may be heavyly biased, as I played the heck out of TD games in my early years and after tons of repetitive flash games, I generally consider all TD's outright boring nowadays.And that's what Sanctum is. A tower defense game, played from a first persion view. You got some weapons, but even if priorizing to upgrade those, it's more like you're assissting the towers in doing their job (f.e. by freezing enemies in tower range, dropping the shields of tanks with precision sniping or killing enemies that can only be attacked from behind).In it's core, it's still just a TD. And, if I may so, a pretty shallow one at that. I've seen and played FLASH tower defense games, YEARS ago, which had mroe varied content, enemies, tactics.Let's add the mediocre graphic onto this and the... well, there is a store, but it's barely communicated. Which is a pity, because the atmosphere was supposed to be a good part about the game.Overall, this title really didn't amaze or catch me.Result: 4/10

												It's difficult and unintuitive to navigate, the UI and controls are poorly designed, when creating a base of operations it feels less like your base and more like a confusing hodgpodge of difficult to navigate structures. Combat is confusing and feels like a poorly designed FPS mashed with some random turrets.Overall, it's a good idea that needs a lot of polish.

number of helpful: 9 of 25 people (36%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
												I find Sanctum's first person tower defense (with heroes) style clunky, boring and overrated. The controls and user interface are the primary source of frustration. At no point do I feel in complete control of my game, unlike in better examples of this concept (Orcs Must Die).The mix of genres presented here doesn't work for my tastes. Basically for Tower Defense I'd rather play a top-down game like Defense Grid, for a first-person shooter co-operative survival mode I'd rather play Left 4 Dead or TF2's MvM mode. For the genre-mix I'd much rather play the Orcs Must Die series. I cannot recommend Sanctum. I would, however be curious to see how the concepts presented here have perhaps been polished in the sequel, Sanctum 2.

												Could be good. But:Can't build during a wave.You have no idea what to build for the next wave (see previous problem)You can't change tower or weapon loadouts once a level is startedYou can't build in overview modeSo basically... no fun at all. You have to memorize each wave to build correctly which means if on wave three one gets to the core, you have to go back to wave one start all over. Then repeat the process for each consecutive wave. 												I really enjoyed Sanctum 2 and I wholeheartedly recommend you buy it.  However, its predecessor is...not good.  Everything Sanctum does, Sanctum 2 does much better.  Sanctum's UI is clunky, tower building is awkward, information on towers that's clearly provided in Sanctum 2 is obfuscated here, gameplay is less fluid and fun; it's just all-around an inferior experience.  If you're like me and thought, "hey Sanctum 2 was great, I'll give the original a try," save your money.

content:
Posted: October 17, 2014
												The co-op mode for this game in unbearable. I played this with one of my friends and we had the best maze possbile with leveled up towers. But guest what! They send either 500 speedy units that you can only kill a few or they said a about 5 giant units with around 10,000,000 hp. I thinking I got this since I upgraded my sniper rifle and the damage ampfing square to the max level doing around 1 million damage per shot. But guest what! There big monsters just laugh at the damage and just go on slowly to your base. There is no stratgeay  when all you do is sit there following the monsters shooting at them. I feel like all the towers don't do anything but add a little damage here and there even though they are full upgraded. The anti air towers are the only good towers. I can tell that the multiplayer was meant for 4 players and if you got anything less than that you're going to lose. The sad thing is your not just going to be killed but your going to be absolutely destroyed. They would kill us and there would still be about 50 more units still alive. To conclude this, I think Orcs Must Die! 2 did the tower defense with fps better. You felt like you could win, you felt like with one more try you could beat the enemy; in this game all I felt like was that the game was just being really cheap and unfair. I just started and the game expected prefection. Although I heard the single player was better. But again, surprise surprise, the levels are so BORING AND LONG. I couldn't recommend this.

number of helpful: 3 of 17 people (18%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 11, 2016
												Tower defense games have been one of my favorite genres since the old days of Warcraft 3 custom maps.  I've played (and thoroughly enjoyed) many TD's, like Deathtrap, Dungeon Defenders 1, Orcs Must Die, and more.But this... ugh.It BOMBARDS you with way too many towers and weapons all at once.  I don't really get why most every tower needs to be built on a block.  I could use more specific information on tower damage to help me learn strengths and weaknesses vs certain enemies.  How do I know which lane is going to be used next?  The graphics are kinda blocky and bad.  Am I really supposed to get on top of a tower and shoot enemies there?  Many of them run so fast I have to chase after them, shooting them in the butt.  The sound effects are generally headache-inducing, especially the menu ones.  And worst of all, being first person means you can't see what's going on.  Even a Dungeon Defenders style of camera would be preferable.On the plus side... uh... honestly, I can't think of a plus side here :(

number of helpful: 6 of 24 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 21, 2014
												Sanctum 2 has much more freedom than this game and is much more fun. I am not a fan of this game although I wanted to be until I very quickly realized how they designed it. You have to be very specific with your tower placement and upgrades to be successful. The ability to play how you want to play is nearly nonexistent. It's like the developers said "we are releasing our game for you to play and you will play it how WE want you to play it, not how you want to play it". You cannot place the towers that you want and certain enemies require gun upgrades moreso than tower upgrades and so on and so forth, and those are just scratching the surface of the large amount of underlying rules that exist within this game's trial-and-error-exclusive play structure that shackle you to playing how they intend you to play and only how they intended. Throw out any thoughts of playing how you want and using any kind of common sense strategy that you have learned from over 90% of other good tower defense games out the window.Needs more freedom 5/10

Posted: May 18, 2011
												Sanctum is a great success of the combining of two genres. So many games try to meld or blur genres and what comes out is a diluted mess of a game. Sanctum is a tower defense game, but when the hoards come you spend your time helping defend the core by sniping air units or slowing down the line of charging bad guys. Both parts of the game are equally important as the towers or your guns won't be enough to beat a level by themselves. There are only 4 maps but each has an endless mode and coop is satisfying, helping the overall replay value. Do yourself a favor and pick this one up.

Posted: July 4, 2011
												I'm not sure why, but Sanctum seems to consistently be relegated to the domain of 'novelty' in most of the material I've seen covering it: from reviews to recommendations, even its own advertisements, this game seems to focus more on the fact that You Can Use Guns than it does on the fact that it's an interesting, deep, challenging Tower Defence with good mechanics and a strong personality.  Even more, the fact that you get guns doesn't really detract from the sheer fun of the Maze-Build-Upgrade gameplay that is at the heart of the genre.  Now, this one is fairly solid-- it has a mazing apparatus built into it, out of which you form your other towers, meaning no space is wasted with powerless towers-- but I wish there was slightly less focus on the gunning aspect of it.  Like I said earlier, the game fixates on this fact, and instead of allowing you to opt-out of firing alongside your towers, several waves in every attempt consist entirely of enemies you must kill yourself.

Posted: July 22, 2012
												There was a time when tower defense games asked you to do one thing – set down defense structures in order to prevent waves of enemy units from destroying your base. All of this was done from a top-down view so that you could see the action without really being in the midst of it all.While there have been recent attempts to change up the genre, like Defenders of Ardania which allowed players to build their own armies, such games have stuck to the top-down perspective and not changed the formulaic gameplay. Other games like Plants vs Zombies, for example, fully embraced the old mechanics but were very successful because of their presentation. Yet only recently have games such as Dungeon Defenders changed the perspective.Sanctum offered me a first-person view of the tower defense action becoming the latest game to do so. No longer having to watch helplessly from the sky and pray that my strategically placed towers would fend off the enemy, I found myself able to take part in defending my base right in the thick of things.Read the rest of my review at Press2Reset: http://press2reset.com/reviews/review-sanctum-collection/

Posted: April 14, 2014
												This game is a phenomenal blend of tower defense and FPS-action.  Teamplay is a must on this as four players yielding their own spending cash will allow the team to maximize their defenses prior to each round as well as upgrading your weaponry.  Many of the monsters have unique weaknesses; however, most of the tower weaponry do not act upon this and will shoot blindly at immune areas of the monsters even if they're upgraded at max level.  This is where FPS-action comes to play as each player will choose from a select range of weaponry each having 2-types of methods of engagement.  Cannot believe this game was on sale for a buck - it's uniqueness and replayability-value definitely makes it a diamond-class addition to your gaming arsenal.  Looking forward to seeing what Sanctum 2 has to offer.

Posted: May 5, 2012
												Essentially the companion to your Dungeon Defenders. Same concept - do something while the waves roll in a tower defence - but this one is sci-fi rather than fantasy, and also first person rather than (mostly) third person.Honestly, since I'm much more of a fan of sci-fi to ye olde, I enjoy this more. Soundtrack is also bloody brilliant, since I'm a fan of that stuff, too. It's a bit daunting at first, waves are pretty damn difficult, but you can get into it easy enough.Also, it has Moonbase Alpha's text to speech. Which renders MA completely useless because this is a game that you play and have fun with, on top of the funny voice. As opposed to just dicking about with that feature and not really accomplishing anything.

Posted: January 31, 2014
												Even though I have only played Sanctum for a short time, I am seduced by it's alluring nature, and as a result of this passionate seduction I have been so involved with the game. I really enjoy and appreciate the combination of a FPS game and a TD; it gives the game and gameplay a little more vivid characteristics and an immensly addictive attraction. The graphics are decent and adds vibrance to the killing scene of poor, helpless little walkers being slaughtered by mortars, lasers and lightning (it even allows you to see the detail of every chunk of the walkers' bodies). The gamplay is easy to adapt to the fact action is pretty much instant gives me a buzz. But it also gives you time to strategically and carefully plan the longest routes and best places to put towers and slowfields. I'm not good at reviews, but here's all I got and I hope the person who reads this abomination of a review gets addicted to Sanctum.
