Posted: April 1, 2014
												Ok, so I decided I would redo my Sanctum 1 review since I did terrible Sanctum 2, so I'll just explain why I prefer THIS one over the 2nd one.PROS:The game itself: I want to point this out to EVERYONE who apparently likes Sanctum 2 better, Sanctum 1 is a tower based game with FPS elements, so you can help your towers out as well as have something to do than just sit there.  The 2nd one is FPS based with towers involved and I HATE that, the best part about the first one was the huge maps, level up weapons, level up towers and killingfloors to high levels to do a s%#ton of damage with, teleport around the place getting in enemies faces, get infront of them to block them off so they couldn't get closer, etc. and that's why I loved it, the FPS part was just there for some entertainment and to help out friends/towers so you would have something to doLarge maps: A good chunk of the maps in this game are actually really big, seriously, some of the maps are ginormous and you have to be careful about where you put your towers, as well as where you should stand to help them out.Weapons/Pick your own weapons: There are multiple weapons to pick from, i'm not going to list them all but i'll say my favorties are R.E.X., the Tesla Gun, and the Sniper, and leveling them up means more damage and more ammo, as well as quicker reload times.  And to top it all off you can pick your weapons instead of being forced 1 weapon, AND you also get 3 weapons instead of 2, making it more fun.Level up weapons: This is another thing I adored about the first one, the level up system for weapons.  How this works is that you switch to your weapon inbetween rounds with SHIFT, and hold LMB (if you have enough money) And it upgrades it to the next level, the higher the level the more damage you do with it, there is a limit but it does a lot of damage.NO. F%$KING. TOWER LIMIT: I hated this SO MUCH about the 2nd, there isn't a tower/block limit, there isn't, if you have the money and it isn't blocking the enemies path then you can put it there, and that's why I liked it, I hate how the 2nd one you have a limit, why a limit? That was one of the great things about the first one.No stupid boss fights: There are no boss fights in this game, and that's another thing I like and don't like, I wish there was a big enemy to fight but in the 2nd one he's just a a$$hole.  Me and my friends spent 20 minutes in Sanctum 2 on the last wave and putting towers in places and making a longer maze for the boss, well apparently the boss gave us a middle finger and plowed through it all, making all of our time and money utterly useless, after we saw that we quit and played the first game again.Towers:  Like I said in the first statement that this is a Tower based game with FPS elements, which means the towers do a good chunk of work and you are the support instead of it being vice versa.  There are multiple types of towers, my personal favorties are the killing floor which sits on the ground, and any enemy that runs over it takes damage, AND slows him down for a few seconds, and theres also this one with a long a$$ neck that pretty snipe enemies from across the map in a few hits.  There are others of course, try em out!Teleport system: If you fall off the map or are wanting to go up to the front/back of the complex to get at enemies or just for the fun of it you can teleport around if you put down some teleport pads, makes it easy to swap around the map and help out friends or to get to enemies quickly instead of running there.You can't die:  Yup, you aren't able to die at all and I like that a lot, it doesn't put a whole lot of tension or anything, if you fall off the map you just pick a place to teleport at with no worries.Core: The Core is what you are trying to protect the aliens from, if too many get in it explodes and you lose, the bigger the enemy the more health it takes off, and you can't get any back, so keep those b@$#ards away from it at all costs.No timer: I hated this about the 2nd as well, in the first inbetween rounds you get no timer, as much time as you need to set up your maze for enemies or put towers in places, get to certain high points for sniping, anything.  In the 2nd inbetween rounds half the time you get like 30 seconds to do whatever it is you have to before it starts and I hated that.Enemy hits: If a enemy hits you you don't lose health or anything, he just knocks you back and shakes your camera around, making it a little woozy, then when your senses come back you can go after the guy that hit you.CONS:Teleport pads: At times when I was playing I would hug against a wall so I wouldn't get knocked back, but I ran back somehow cause a telepad came down to pick me up and I went back too far and into the hoard on the other side and I kind of got stuck.  I don't know if this is a nitpick or something that people hate cause my friends do it constantly as well and they get annoyed with it.Towers: Some towers feel utterly useless, for instance there is a slow-pad for the floor like a Killing Floor is used, it slows the enemies down alot but doesn't do damage, when the Killing Floor does damage and slows them down abit.  And some are useful for only certain types, for instance gattling guns are for ground units only, and missile launchers for air targets only, some of them are mixed though, so they hit both air and ground units.Longer waves mean harder enemies: When you upgrade all of your towers and weapons you would imagine you would be set, sadly that isn't true, as waves go on enemies get harder and harder with each wave, one time I had all of my towers (except 2-3) and all of my weapons upgraded and I was expecting to wipe the floor with everyone, but halfway through the wave the enemies were getting past my maze pretty quickly, and still had chunks of health left so I had to go back to the core and pick them off one by one, I lost sadly.  I would recommend you play with friends that way you can all gang up on the aliens.WHAT I THINK:  I think this was the actual good game of the 2, even half of my friends who played the 1st and 2nd prefer the 1st one instead, I still play this game on occassion because it's still entertaining to me, and I love it for that, it has quite high replayability, and the text-to-voice chat system is just downright hilarious, I give this game a 8/10, it needs some fixing with some things but it's still very fun all around.  Worth it on a sale or as it sits!

Posted: July 12, 2011
												I really enjoy this game.It's a great mixture of the Tower Defence genre, which I am a huge fan of, and First Person Shooter which I am a lesser fan of. What's great is that where most TDs can leave you sitting idily waiting for mobs to die so you can keep building up your towers, Sanctum has you in the frey often doing a good bit of the work to hit enemy weak-spots while your towers slowly damage the mobs, or mop up straglers.The game goes in rounds of building and fighting, and you can always see what monster types are coming, but not in what number, or how much HP they have. You can upgrade any tower to level 6, with doubling costs each time, or even improve your own firepower. You have three weapons, an assult rifle, sniper rile, and freeze-gun which all give you different rolls you can play around the battlefield, or as the situation may require.You can play online with others as they build and fight at the same time. I've yet to do so, but it sounds like a blast.

Posted: November 28, 2011
												Coffee Stain Studios originally sold me a half-finished game for $15. When they promised on their forum to add new content to the game, they failed to tell their customers that it would be a la carte (DLC) - all for an additional $11. I, along with others, was enraged by this and decided to stop playing altogether. A few months later, however, I changed my mind after a recent 75% off Steam sale. I decided that paying an additional $2 for the completed game seemed reasonable. These recent improvements have indeed made Sanctum more challenging and enjoyable. Therefore, I humbly (yet grudgingly) give CSS a tip of the hat for making a good game.

Posted: March 16, 2014
												Great combination of thinking and shooting. I had not personally seen a game like Sanctum before. I had played a tower defense game before, particularly on Android mobile, but this was the first that blended tower defense and FPS genres. Multiplayer shows the attitude difference between players who just want to shoot aliens and take all the glory versus players that want to build the optimal defense maze and let the machines do most of the work. The map artwork is visually wonderful and map design is suitably puzzling in the possibilities and limitations of maze layout. Finding the easter eggs in each level is kinda fun too.Very much recommended, at least for the awesome cackling female laugh of the main character.

Posted: February 24, 2014
												When I first saw this game, it was just an Unreal Engine 3 mod. While unimpressive at first, I thought the original idea of merging fps shooter and tower defense could evolve. Needless to say now, evolve it did, and it has it all. Intense strategical planning, fast reaction and true aim are vital to your success on higher difficulties. The game brings a great multiplayer experience especally while playing with friends.Although it's tower defense, it keeps a lot of pressure on the players, as they remain the main source of damage during the 1-2 hour-long battles. The team has to focus on most important targets at a time in order to succeed. Unfortunately, there are no checkpoints in multiplayer...The downside of Sanctum is, despite the waves of monsters being randomized, a limited amount of their variations, only a few levels and so things might get repetitive.Personally I enjoy the game very much and prefer it over its sequel.

Posted: July 12, 2011
												I really enjoy this game.It's a great mixture of the Tower Defence genre, which I am a huge fan of, and First Person Shooter which I am a lesser fan of. What's great is that where most TDs can leave you sitting idily waiting for mobs to die so you can keep building up your towers, Sanctum has you in the frey often doing a good bit of the work to hit enemy weak-spots while your towers slowly damage the mobs, or mop up straglers.The game goes in rounds of building and fighting, and you can always see what monster types are coming, but not in what number, or how much HP they have. You can upgrade any tower to level 6, with doubling costs each time, or even improve your own firepower. You have three weapons, an assult rifle, sniper rile, and freeze-gun which all give you different rolls you can play around the battlefield, or as the situation may require.You can play online with others as they build and fight at the same time. I've yet to do so, but it sounds like a blast.

												This is a fantastic blend of tower defense and FPS. Posted: February 20, 2015
												OK Let's start with the warning. FOR ALL OF YOU PEOPLE LOOKING FOR AN EASY GAME TO COMPLETE: DO NOT BUY THIS GAME!Sanctum is HARD! You can't go in with a mentality of, "oh it's just a shooter, Ill just blast everything away!" or "oh it's just a tower defence, I'll just upgrade my towers" No, you must enter Sanctum with the mentality of," Ok, Ill start a small maze with lazers on top to defend agains air and ground, and near the end I'll wait and snipe the bobbleheads as they come." YES This game requires planning! So if you want a mindless shooter, look elsewhere. For all of you people who want to just try to upgrade your towers, you must realize that some creatures are going to be missed and head strait for your core ( the place you are defending ). Creatures like bobbleheads are only damaged in certain spots, and will not be killed easily by towers. YOU have to kill these guys, and soakers, I can't forget those damage loving guys. YOUR WEAPONS!All of the weapons are fun and easy to use! They all overheat/ need to be reloaded after constant use. The more you upgrade them the more ammo/coolant you have so upgrade them as much as possible. They are your rudimentary assult rifle, sniper, rocket launcher, and freeze ray (pardon me if I missed some) Wait, freeze rays aren't rudimentary! And you have towers which act as elevators, walls, lazers, lightning bolts, and more, and every tower can be upgraded, (except for the elevator because I mean really... :P) Each tower targets the air, the ground, or both!To be completely honest if you have the right mentallity you can play this game and beat it ( and then go get DLC and beat it some more ) in a few months (yes months you speed players MONTHS)  THIS GAME IS RATED 9/10 FUEGO SCORE!

Posted: October 16, 2012
												So I started playing Sanctum last time they had a free weekend (like a year ago?) I didn't buy it then, but I bought it now. I think this is my new favorite Tower Defense game. It happens to also be an FPS. So you walk around the map, laying down your towers of varying types (as in any TD game). Then when the action starts, not only do your towers start shooting, but so do you. So while your turrets are killing aliens, you're running and jumping and shooting them as well.At first I was like "Meh. Whatever. I'll let my towers do all the work and just keep an eye on things and mop up any leaks." Nope. You can't win at this game without a good tower strategy AND a good supplemental sniper rifle strategy.For example, there are certain enemies that are armored and take zero damage until a shot to the head makes them vulnerable for about ten seconds. Once in a while, a tower will get lucky. But most of the time you need to do that♥♥♥♥♥♥yourself.So I give Sanctum an A-.

Posted: April 13, 2013
												Sanctum is probably one of the most fun I've had in a tower defense game. It mixes tower defense with a first person shooter, which really mixes up the combat. You have a huge variety of turrets and weapons. Each level starts off a blank slate and you choose where to place blocks, creating the enemy AI pathing. These blocks can be upgraded to any turret or platform you want. There is also this thing they call a transelevator (or something similiar) that you can use to either transport to another one on the map or use it to get ontop of that block and walk along the high blocks, perfect for when your shooting your own weapons, like the Assualt rifle, sniper rifle or the slow enemies down weaopon. Each gun has alternative fires/modes. I really recommend this game to people who are tired of ToD games or have never tried one before. It's a fresh change that I really liked.

Posted: February 29, 2012
												An FPS Tower Defense Game - not 100% original, however this one pulled it off really well.  It took me about 4.5 hours to beat the single player set of 6 levels or so.  Some of the levels have 30 waves and can take an hour or two.This follows the same basic concept as a normal tower defense game.  You survive waves of attacks and you get points.  You use the points for new turrets or upgrades to the old ones.  The twist is that you can also upgrade your guns so you can help destroy the enemys in FPS fashion as they run through the tower defense path.I did find the game really easy once I placed Scatter Laser everywhere and kept upgrading my shotgun/sniper rifle.  The first two levels learning the game gave me more trouble than the last three levels by the time I figured it out.  On normal I got 100% on the last three levels.Anyways, totally cool if you love Tower Defense... don't buy if you love FPS because it is more of a tower defense than FPS.

DID YOU EVER WISH TO BE ABLE TO SHOOT THE ENEMIES YOURSELF TOO?Well,with this game,you can.you are given a number of weapons which can be upgraded with the same money which is used to build towers.But more information later.Sanctum is a First Person Tower defense,where you build,upgrade your towers or weapons,stare at the dead multiplayer or play in single playerthere are different enemy types,for example,there are some which have a shield where you deal lower damage against,unless you shoot the weak spot enough.or enemies which fly.the controls(movement) are good,but it takes some time to get used to the game mechanics.So its recommended to see the tutorial.unless you already know first person TD gamesYou cannot die,you just get pushed back a whole bunch when you run into the enemies.make out of that what ever you want.Your weapons also do not require ammo,however,they can overheat,but you can us them after some seconds again,so do not worry.Do you recommend this?yes.a clear yes.its something i haven't seen before,with enemies i also already know(Super Sanctum TD since i played that one first)and the fact that you can shoot yourself in the game is also fun.if you aren't a fan of games like those where you can active shoot and do something while the wave happens,its nothing for you.maybe check it out on Youtube if you aren't sure,or just wait when this game is in sale.

												100% YES!!!Some of you guys probably thought that this will be another tower defense game (on the beginning i was also in that group - but not anymore). ...and yes you are right. Your goal is to kill enemy monsters before they will reach your power core. It looks like another tower defense game but not the kind you know.It is full 3D First Person Tower Defense shooter game. You and your towers defending together in real-time action.You can select up to 3 weapons for every map: choose wisely between assault guns, sniper rifles, lasers, rocket launchers, freezers and much more. Make your enemy's life a hell creating mazes and extending their path of agony. Game is divided into two parts: building and fight phase.While in build phase you can build/demolish or upgrade. You can upgrade towers and/or  your weapon. This is very important part cause every wave will encounter other group of monsters.Don't worry all time you have access to monsterpedia where you can check and see monster's weak spots. You are still not convinced ... ok .. you can defend the core with your friends in co-op mode. Game is worth to try! Lot's of hard work but also great fun, grab all 100 achievements and be the best on Global leaderboard. Game is based on Unreal Engine 3, you know what that mean ... beautiful graphics and nice game physic.If you are looking for similar game, that would be Orcs Must Die! 2 . Both games will give you lots of fun.Buy It, try It, Like It, Play It.Have Fun.

Posted: June 13, 2015
												"Sanctum" is...okay.The game's main interest lies in how it shows Coffee Stain's ability to iterate. The lessons that the team learned from "Sanctum" are very visible in "Sanctum 2," a noticeably more polished title. This entry in the series is a decent diversion for a day or two, but it never gets beyond that.This is not to say that the original game is bad - it's just to point out that there are some very noticeable rough edges. In comparison to the sequel, the character handling in "Sanctum" feels clunky and imprecise. The tower building is much more of a chore, and just getting around the map feels a bit awkward.The game pacing is also "clunky." Each map lasts for what feels like an extraordinarily long time, without really building much tension to keep things interesting. This feeling of things being overlong also tends to create outsize punishments for choosing a bad tower loadout or overall strategy. If you chase yourself into a situation that suddenly becomes unwinnable at a late wave, the reaction is NOT one of "Oh - I see what might work!" Instead, my feeling was "Ugh...I have to do all that again? *Sigh...*"Part of the problem is that the game is so contextless. I feel that it's a perfect example of a multiplayer game that just happens to have a working singleplayer mode. Unlike its sequel, "Sanctum" has no worldbuilding, characters, or sense of purpose that makes you invest in the game's progression. It's just a collection of disconnected encounters that happen to you, and while some of the defense problems are interesting to solve, there's a lot of repetition. It might be better with multiplayer co-op, where some of the social aspects serve to spice things up independent of the software.If the gameplay was truly a blast, the above wouldn't be as much of a liability. It doesn't make it to that point, though.So, with all the apparent negativity, why would I still click "Yes" when asked if I recommend "Sanctum?"Well, first, reviewers need a third option: A "Maybe" button. But beyond that...I do feel that "Sanctum" is worth seeing as a curiosity. It provides a kind of window into how the series was formed and refined. Play time isn't everything, but in this case, I think there's a strong correlation. "Sanctum 2" was brilliant enough to keep me playing for almost 40 hours, which is more than four times longer than I was willing to spend with "Sanctum." It may be that "Sanctum" is only about 1/4 as good as its dramatically improved sequel. It certainly feels that way to me, and maybe that's just good enough to spend a few bucks on.In other words, the game is pretty "Eh," but I don't hate it.

Posted: November 28, 2011
												Coffee Stain Studios originally sold me a half-finished game for $15. When they promised on their forum to add new content to the game, they failed to tell their customers that it would be a la carte (DLC) - all for an additional $11. I, along with others, was enraged by this and decided to stop playing altogether. A few months later, however, I changed my mind after a recent 75% off Steam sale. I decided that paying an additional $2 for the completed game seemed reasonable. These recent improvements have indeed made Sanctum more challenging and enjoyable. Therefore, I humbly (yet grudgingly) give CSS a tip of the hat for making a good game.

Posted: March 16, 2014
												Great combination of thinking and shooting. I had not personally seen a game like Sanctum before. I had played a tower defense game before, particularly on Android mobile, but this was the first that blended tower defense and FPS genres. Multiplayer shows the attitude difference between players who just want to shoot aliens and take all the glory versus players that want to build the optimal defense maze and let the machines do most of the work. The map artwork is visually wonderful and map design is suitably puzzling in the possibilities and limitations of maze layout. Finding the easter eggs in each level is kinda fun too.Very much recommended, at least for the awesome cackling female laugh of the main character.

Posted: June 7, 2011
												If you have $15 burning a hole in your pocket, this isn't the worst way to spend it.  The game is a lot of fun and if you like tower defense games and first person shooters, this is a near perfect blend betwen the two.  Offering several ways to win each round, you can play each map more than one time. .... however this is where the game has it's downfall.   For $15 you only get FOUR maps, which is the entirety of the game.  I think I had finished this game in five hours, and played through it twice in less than nine hours.   At that point I was bored with it and wished it had been much longer.Ultimately I give this game 2 stars out of five.  Everything the game does, it does pretty well, but you'll chew through that content very quickly and be left hungry for more.... but not in a good way.  Ultimately the game feels half finished and I ended the game almost feeling like I had paid $15 for a demo.  This game could easily be 3 or 4 times as long with the addition of more maps.

Posted: January 3, 2015
A Worthy PurchaseI bought two copies of Sanctum this sale for $3. It was totally worth it.The game is tower defense and FPS combined. Both are well balanced and you cannot complete a single level without a good balance of the two, which is ideal. The Co-Op is quite fun too, just make sure that you can communicate properly.Each level is unique. The first 3 took me 4 hours; some trial and error involved. But, surprisingly, every time I failed I was not frustrated at all because the checkpoints are smartly and generously placed in levels. The game is really enjoyable.The game is totally worth it and please do buy it.

content:

												Sanctum is a competent tower defence game combined with a fun FPS aspect. This combination, although it may sound strange, works like a charm. There is nothing more satisfying in this game than setting up an impressive defense which obliterates all foes, and destroying anything left with a huge plast from your Rex.An arsenal of weapons and tower choices makes this game diverse, and even more fun to play with friends to gt the best combination possible.A very solid game, and an excellent multiplayer experience make this a joy to play.

Posted: February 20, 2015
												OK Let's start with the warning. FOR ALL OF YOU PEOPLE LOOKING FOR AN EASY GAME TO COMPLETE: DO NOT BUY THIS GAME!Sanctum is HARD! You can't go in with a mentality of, "oh it's just a shooter, Ill just blast everything away!" or "oh it's just a tower defence, I'll just upgrade my towers" No, you must enter Sanctum with the mentality of," Ok, Ill start a small maze with lazers on top to defend agains air and ground, and near the end I'll wait and snipe the bobbleheads as they come." YES This game requires planning! So if you want a mindless shooter, look elsewhere. For all of you people who want to just try to upgrade your towers, you must realize that some creatures are going to be missed and head strait for your core ( the place you are defending ). Creatures like bobbleheads are only damaged in certain spots, and will not be killed easily by towers. YOU have to kill these guys, and soakers, I can't forget those damage loving guys. YOUR WEAPONS!All of the weapons are fun and easy to use! They all overheat/ need to be reloaded after constant use. The more you upgrade them the more ammo/coolant you have so upgrade them as much as possible. They are your rudimentary assult rifle, sniper, rocket launcher, and freeze ray (pardon me if I missed some) Wait, freeze rays aren't rudimentary! And you have towers which act as elevators, walls, lazers, lightning bolts, and more, and every tower can be upgraded, (except for the elevator because I mean really... :P) Each tower targets the air, the ground, or both!To be completely honest if you have the right mentallity you can play this game and beat it ( and then go get DLC and beat it some more ) in a few months (yes months you speed players MONTHS)  THIS GAME IS RATED 9/10 FUEGO SCORE!

												Essentially the companion to your Dungeon Defenders. Same concept - do something while the waves roll in a tower defence - but this one is sci-fi rather than fantasy, and also first person rather than (mostly) third person.Honestly, since I'm much more of a fan of sci-fi to ye olde, I enjoy this more. Soundtrack is also bloody brilliant, since I'm a fan of that stuff, too. It's a bit daunting at first, waves are pretty damn difficult, but you can get into it easy enough.Also, it has Moonbase Alpha's text to speech. Which renders MA completely useless because this is a game that you play and have fun with, on top of the funny voice. As opposed to just dicking about with that feature and not really accomplishing anything.

Posted: July 12, 2011
												I was a little skeptical since I have never been huge into tower defense games but I do enjoy a good FPS from time to time. This game does an excelent job of merging the two. I was somewhat concerned with how the game was going to pull off object placement and interaction but it manages to pull it off with a wonderfully intuitive interface. Being able to jump into the battle also gives it an edge over other tower defense games.It could stand a few more maps, at present It has 5 maps. However I feel compelled to mention how detailed these maps seem to be, if one chooses to explore around to see what is hidden in them.My only regret so far is that I wish I had snagged the 4 pack.

Posted: July 16, 2012
												This is a pretty nice take on tower defense. The shooting difficulty is appropriate, the pacing is perfect, and the towers are what you'd expect from any tower defense game that knows what it's doing. The single Big Walkers are a total cheat, but you can get through them. Just make sure you can keep from losing forty percent of your core's life. Preparation is key, and the game encourages routing & tower placement. Don't expect to be successful with shooting alone.The soundtrack is great. It's a mix of electronica that intermingles with the style of the game well. It - like many tower defense games - makes heavy use of sci-fi aesthetics, so the soundtrack is appropriate and welcome. The only beef I have is that some tracks are reused on some maps. I'd say pick this up if you have any interest in tower defense or tactical turn-based games & get the soundtrack while you're at it.

Posted: January 30, 2015
												Possibly the only TD I'll ever play, and for one reason: this one makes you an integral part of the action.Build your maze, build your turrets, co-ordinate with a buddy (or three), and blow up some alien critters. The upgrade system is intuitive and interesting as both your turrets and weapons can be upgraded, making both you and your maze a force to be reckoned with. Having a gun in your hand and seeing things in a first person perspective is really what sets this apart from the other TDs where you build your turrets and sit back, letting them do all the work. Depending on the enemy wave, you could sit back and watch your turrets annihilate the enemy, or you could build gigantic, winding maze and do all the dirty work yourself, but eventually it'll balance out to where both you and your turrets are splitting the damage fairly evenly and concentrating your upgrades on either weapons or turrets will lead to failure.As an added bonus, the scenery is absolutely gorgeous in the surreal areas you'll be visiting; there is some astounding artistry put into this.

Posted: March 23, 2015
												Sanctum isn't the very first with this idea in mind, however it pulls it off with amazing gameplay and many viable options.  I don't have the DLC for this, but I can already recommend this game to people with a good group of friends for an online multiplayer romp of PvE.  Now, before we get to the core of this review, let me say this: Soul Masters was the first to attempt this style of gameplay with a mixture of magic, building, and minions.  In that game, you controlled a single character capable of building towers and upgrades, much like that of any tower defense game.  You can use your character to battle across the map and lead your minions to victory.  You build defense structures and upgrade your minions and yourself (if memery serves me well).  The only problem: the game was short-lived and free-to-play.  It's in development limbo, as it was set to re-release, correcting some of the more severe bugs. Now then, on to the review.  The graphics definitely are limited, but get the job done beautifully.  THe enemy designs are a bit lacking, but at least the weak points are easy to spot.  By no means are they unique, but they work well, nonetheless.On to the sounds.  I haven't messed much with the text to speech, but from what I hear, everything fits perfectly together.  The announcer lets you know what mode you're in and the sounds of weapons going off are adequet.  I just wish there was more to it than that, but the music is also adequet and fits the mood.Gameplay: it's a tower defense game.  It's also an FPS.  It WILL get repetitive, but the beauty of it is that you can't favor one over the other.  Achieving balance is important to winning against the waves of enemies.  Some require heavy weapon fire while others require pin-point accuracy to their weaknesses.  Balance what you upgrade and you can make ith trhough.Controls: Here, I have to dock it a little because there's no option to run, so you're moving kinda slow through the building process, but then again, you're building and you have unlimited time to build until you hit enter.  Still, the controls are solid and the aiming is what you'd expect from any FPS game.  Sniping is as easy as it is in most other FPS games, which is never a bad thing.Overall: I'd give this game a definite 9/10, would like to see more people play this, but the sequel is already out there, so I suggest getting that over this, as long as the gameplay mechanics only improve over what this game has already done.  Still, if you can pick this one up, it's definitely a keeper.  I hope to grab the sequel someday soon.

Posted: November 5, 2011
												This game is one of those sleeper hits, where it gets released with little fanfare and attracts a small-but-loyal following.  I have to say, though, that where this game has gone since that time is quite amazing!  It started out as a very beautiful, atmospheric, strategic tower defense game and still has all of those elements, but Coffee Stain Studios has gone completely above and beyond in developing DLC content for it.  The newest update and DLC maps are so incredible and light-years ahead of the original game.  I started playing this game the day it was released and I recommended it to friends then - I definitely recommend it now!  There's an entire game within the game exploring the lush landscapes and basketloads of Easter eggs hidden in what is already a solid game.  Don't be an idiot, buy it!

Product received for free
												Hit the Glowy Bit for Massive Damage: The Game.Graphics: The design of each weapon and tower is unique and interesting. The textures and model quality is appealing. Each map has a very well designed setting and atmosphere.Gameplay: While not a unique concept, this is the first time I've seen a TD/FPS hybrid work effectively. You must achieve a balance between hand-held weapons and automated turrets, which was done quite effectively.Controls: For the most part, intuitive. Building, combat, and movement is easy to get a hang of. I'm kind of disapointed with the lack of sprinting or crouching, but it doesn't detract that much. The character controls well, similar but not quite exactly like in a Source game.Content: To be honest, it's kind of lacking. The DLC helps a bit, but it doesn't help the fact that overall, each map is pretty much the same and there's a very limited selection of towers and guns.Overall, a very well done game, but Sanctum II is preferable.

Posted: July 12, 2011
												I really enjoy this game.It's a great mixture of the Tower Defence genre, which I am a huge fan of, and First Person Shooter which I am a lesser fan of. What's great is that where most TDs can leave you sitting idily waiting for mobs to die so you can keep building up your towers, Sanctum has you in the frey often doing a good bit of the work to hit enemy weak-spots while your towers slowly damage the mobs, or mop up straglers.The game goes in rounds of building and fighting, and you can always see what monster types are coming, but not in what number, or how much HP they have. You can upgrade any tower to level 6, with doubling costs each time, or even improve your own firepower. You have three weapons, an assult rifle, sniper rile, and freeze-gun which all give you different rolls you can play around the battlefield, or as the situation may require.You can play online with others as they build and fight at the same time. I've yet to do so, but it sounds like a blast.

Posted: February 29, 2012
												An FPS Tower Defense Game - not 100% original, however this one pulled it off really well.  It took me about 4.5 hours to beat the single player set of 6 levels or so.  Some of the levels have 30 waves and can take an hour or two.This follows the same basic concept as a normal tower defense game.  You survive waves of attacks and you get points.  You use the points for new turrets or upgrades to the old ones.  The twist is that you can also upgrade your guns so you can help destroy the enemys in FPS fashion as they run through the tower defense path.I did find the game really easy once I placed Scatter Laser everywhere and kept upgrading my shotgun/sniper rifle.  The first two levels learning the game gave me more trouble than the last three levels by the time I figured it out.  On normal I got 100% on the last three levels.Anyways, totally cool if you love Tower Defense... don't buy if you love FPS because it is more of a tower defense than FPS.

												On sale for a mere £1.74, it's high time I recommended Sanctum. The gameplay is decent. A freestyle maze construction tower defence that becomes an FPS when the monsters start coming with 4 player multiplayer built in. Where Sanctum really shines is in its lore. Posted: January 21, 2013
												The marriage of tower defense and FPS never felt so right. With tight controls and excellent art direction, Sanctum delivers a pleasant mix of strategy and execution. Plan your defenses well and you can rest your trigger finger while watching your enemies helplessly march into the jaws of your death machine. Plan them poorly and it becomes a panic storm of overheating weapons and critical hits. Gameplay is forgiving to the beginner, but the higher difficulties reward tactics and design. Coffee Stain Studios have presented a brilliant proof of concept that tickles all the right parts of my brain. I can't wait for the sequel.

Posted: November 12, 2016
Product received for free
												Hit the Glowy Bit for Massive Damage: The Game.Graphics: The design of each weapon and tower is unique and interesting. The textures and model quality is appealing. Each map has a very well designed setting and atmosphere.Gameplay: While not a unique concept, this is the first time I've seen a TD/FPS hybrid work effectively. You must achieve a balance between hand-held weapons and automated turrets, which was done quite effectively.Controls: For the most part, intuitive. Building, combat, and movement is easy to get a hang of. I'm kind of disapointed with the lack of sprinting or crouching, but it doesn't detract that much. The character controls well, similar but not quite exactly like in a Source game.Content: To be honest, it's kind of lacking. The DLC helps a bit, but it doesn't help the fact that overall, each map is pretty much the same and there's a very limited selection of towers and guns.Overall, a very well done game, but Sanctum II is preferable.

Posted: June 13, 2015
												"Sanctum" is...okay.The game's main interest lies in how it shows Coffee Stain's ability to iterate. The lessons that the team learned from "Sanctum" are very visible in "Sanctum 2," a noticeably more polished title. This entry in the series is a decent diversion for a day or two, but it never gets beyond that.This is not to say that the original game is bad - it's just to point out that there are some very noticeable rough edges. In comparison to the sequel, the character handling in "Sanctum" feels clunky and imprecise. The tower building is much more of a chore, and just getting around the map feels a bit awkward.The game pacing is also "clunky." Each map lasts for what feels like an extraordinarily long time, without really building much tension to keep things interesting. This feeling of things being overlong also tends to create outsize punishments for choosing a bad tower loadout or overall strategy. If you chase yourself into a situation that suddenly becomes unwinnable at a late wave, the reaction is NOT one of "Oh - I see what might work!" Instead, my feeling was "Ugh...I have to do all that again? *Sigh...*"Part of the problem is that the game is so contextless. I feel that it's a perfect example of a multiplayer game that just happens to have a working singleplayer mode. Unlike its sequel, "Sanctum" has no worldbuilding, characters, or sense of purpose that makes you invest in the game's progression. It's just a collection of disconnected encounters that happen to you, and while some of the defense problems are interesting to solve, there's a lot of repetition. It might be better with multiplayer co-op, where some of the social aspects serve to spice things up independent of the software.If the gameplay was truly a blast, the above wouldn't be as much of a liability. It doesn't make it to that point, though.So, with all the apparent negativity, why would I still click "Yes" when asked if I recommend "Sanctum?"Well, first, reviewers need a third option: A "Maybe" button. But beyond that...I do feel that "Sanctum" is worth seeing as a curiosity. It provides a kind of window into how the series was formed and refined. Play time isn't everything, but in this case, I think there's a strong correlation. "Sanctum 2" was brilliant enough to keep me playing for almost 40 hours, which is more than four times longer than I was willing to spend with "Sanctum." It may be that "Sanctum" is only about 1/4 as good as its dramatically improved sequel. It certainly feels that way to me, and maybe that's just good enough to spend a few bucks on.In other words, the game is pretty "Eh," but I don't hate it.

Posted: March 23, 2015
												Sanctum isn't the very first with this idea in mind, however it pulls it off with amazing gameplay and many viable options.  I don't have the DLC for this, but I can already recommend this game to people with a good group of friends for an online multiplayer romp of PvE.  Now, before we get to the core of this review, let me say this: Soul Masters was the first to attempt this style of gameplay with a mixture of magic, building, and minions.  In that game, you controlled a single character capable of building towers and upgrades, much like that of any tower defense game.  You can use your character to battle across the map and lead your minions to victory.  You build defense structures and upgrade your minions and yourself (if memery serves me well).  The only problem: the game was short-lived and free-to-play.  It's in development limbo, as it was set to re-release, correcting some of the more severe bugs. Now then, on to the review.  The graphics definitely are limited, but get the job done beautifully.  THe enemy designs are a bit lacking, but at least the weak points are easy to spot.  By no means are they unique, but they work well, nonetheless.On to the sounds.  I haven't messed much with the text to speech, but from what I hear, everything fits perfectly together.  The announcer lets you know what mode you're in and the sounds of weapons going off are adequet.  I just wish there was more to it than that, but the music is also adequet and fits the mood.Gameplay: it's a tower defense game.  It's also an FPS.  It WILL get repetitive, but the beauty of it is that you can't favor one over the other.  Achieving balance is important to winning against the waves of enemies.  Some require heavy weapon fire while others require pin-point accuracy to their weaknesses.  Balance what you upgrade and you can make ith trhough.Controls: Here, I have to dock it a little because there's no option to run, so you're moving kinda slow through the building process, but then again, you're building and you have unlimited time to build until you hit enter.  Still, the controls are solid and the aiming is what you'd expect from any FPS game.  Sniping is as easy as it is in most other FPS games, which is never a bad thing.Overall: I'd give this game a definite 9/10, would like to see more people play this, but the sequel is already out there, so I suggest getting that over this, as long as the gameplay mechanics only improve over what this game has already done.  Still, if you can pick this one up, it's definitely a keeper.  I hope to grab the sequel someday soon.

Posted: October 14, 2012
												Sanctum is controlled first-person shooter-style in two phases. The first phase, the building phase, gives you all the time in the world to build your perfect tower maze with whatever resources you have available to you. The second phase, the extermination phase, sends a wave of creeps down your maze. You're even allowed to get in on the fun by blasting them to bits. Enemies will never attack, so, just like any other tower defense game, your only job is to kill them before they reach the end of the maze. If an enemy bumps into you, it will just stun you for a moment and then let you get back to blasting. It's a lot of fun for anyone who gets a kick out of seeing wave after wave of enemies die without resistance.If you're a fan of tower defense games, Sanctum would be a good choice should you decide to add it to your Steam Library :-)

												Surprisingly performance intensive, this Indy game is a very clever combination of an FPS and a Tower Deffence game. With wonderful environments to play in, Sanctum is a very visually-pleasing game in places. A few drawbacks such as a poor selection of hand-help weapons (Not Tower-mounted weapons; there's plenty of those), a lack of player-damage does take the Action-Filled FPS aspect out slightly, but the challenging Waves and special enemies do leave you requiring strategic thinking to win. Fun and exciting, well worth it if you've got the money.

												A Co-op focused tower defense/FPS that takes the strengths of each genre to create a wonderful finished product. The addictiveness of the tower defense compliments the challenge of the difficulty and variation of FPSes perfectly, add in a few friends and you'll be urprised at the coordination required to succeed even on medium difficulty. But the challenge is welcome as there is really no benefit to winning other than saying you did, nothing to unlock and since there is a lot of variation between each play through its not a pain in the♥♥♥♥♥to start over on the same level several times. Although games do tend to last a fairly long time depending on how fast you and your teamate build/spend/upgrade, and with a lack of a save feature in multiplayer (as far as I know) its not a game you can just play for half an hour.Overall the game is very entertaining, and with the price its worth it for even the single player.

Posted: March 7, 2016
												Update:Just finished the main game (six maps without any DLCs) and I had a good time with it.First of all: you need a lot of patience.The gameplay is split in two phases:first you set up your blocks and defenses,second you let the aliens come and take part in the action.From my point of view you can neither play it as a pure TD nor as a pure FPS,though I have not tried that out yet.You can finish a map in about an hour (and a half at most).You choose your weapons and defenses at the beginning of a map, should you be unhappy with your choices you have to start over. There is a checkpoint-system in place for every map.I like the graphics, look very polished to me; you can wander around on the maps, that is nice.The music/soundtrack is awesome.There is a co-op mode, I had not yet the opportunity to try that out.Summary: I recommend this game (with soundtrack!) to all TD-lovers and FPS-enjoyers, at the very least on a discount.-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Original review:1st map: awesome game.2nd map: hmm, well, this is becoming quite challenging.3rd map: difficulty spike... "thou shall not pass"... and it is not those evil aliens which are meant... ;)Only recommended on a discount WITH soundtrack and if you are an absolute TD-lover and enjoy FPS every now and then.Otherwise skip it.

Posted: January 21, 2013
												The marriage of tower defense and FPS never felt so right. With tight controls and excellent art direction, Sanctum delivers a pleasant mix of strategy and execution. Plan your defenses well and you can rest your trigger finger while watching your enemies helplessly march into the jaws of your death machine. Plan them poorly and it becomes a panic storm of overheating weapons and critical hits. Gameplay is forgiving to the beginner, but the higher difficulties reward tactics and design. Coffee Stain Studios have presented a brilliant proof of concept that tickles all the right parts of my brain. I can't wait for the sequel.

Posted: May 13, 2013
												Sanctum is similar to the classical Tower Defence game. Unlike the usual aerial-view, this game becomes a first-person shooter environment. Each towers comes with different abilities and upgrades, to defeat various enemies. You are able to carry three weapons as well. Each item allows you to upgrade to Level 6. How you plan your enemies' path can determine the winning.For Mutiplayer, the co-op mode allows you to have up to 4 players. Hosting a round is fairly easy, and the matchmaking service is awesome. There isn't much latency difference. However every round ends, you are need to rehost the round again. This might be a hassle to get back the same players.

Posted: January 28, 2015
												Hey everyone and this is my review about the game!This is a First person shooter tower defence game.Interface/Menu/SettingsYou can play the game with a controller.There is a tutorial available.You can play the game online. The game is pretty much dead, So you might have to host it.There are many different languages available.There are many different resolution sizes available.You are able to play fullscreen or windowed mode.There is a mouse sensitivity bar meter.There is a master volume bar meter.There is a special effect bar meter.There is an ambient effect bar meter.There is a voice volume bar meter.There is a music volume bar meter.Able to toggle the Text to speech. (if you chat ingame with text, the text will be voiced).Able to customise your controls on the keyboard.About the game.Like many other Tower defence games, You have to build up your own maze where the aliens will be walking through. You are able to place defences on top of the maze to fire at the aliens. The aliens will have to reach your core and destroy it in order to lose. You can also use your own weapons to help during the fights. You can upgrade your towers and pick a variety of weapons.You can even upgrade your weapons at the cost of resources.Music is okay.Graphics is okay.Upgradeable towers and weapons.Has Difficulty settings.Sometimes the enemies are a bit too unfair or too much to handle.There is a mini-map available. If you presss Tab. You can't move however.Pressing the Escape bar will show you the next incoming enemy including their stats and weakness.Other things.When turned on to voice text: HHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHHH.-------------------I Give this game a 6/10

Posted: April 15
												I've sort of held off writing a review for this game for a while now, but I think writing one for its 6th birthday would be a good time.(DISCLAIMER: I know the sequel is probably better and more worth the money to most people, but I'd like to recommend them both.)This is a hybrid of FPS, co-op and tower defense, with the tower defense aspect being the most obvious. There are quite a few types of enemies, each with their own weakspots and towers to counter them.When I first looked at some gameplay, and playing it myself, this game looked older than 2011, but it's surprisingly polished. You can play this with your friends in a co-op mode, which is really fun and challenging.The only fair downside I can see for this game is probably only a problem for me and my toaster computer. The framerates you get on this game doesn't make it ''unplayable'' but for low-end computers it won't run that good.In my opinion, this game deserves way more attention than it gets. 7/10.
